stem: A 17-year-old client with extreme anorexia nervosa (BMI 13.2) reports sharp abdominal pain and vomiting after every meal. Based on the provided documentation, what is the most likely cause of the client's symptoms?

rationale.correct: The most likely cause is **Superior Mesenteric Artery (SMA) Syndrome (a1)**. In patients with rapid weight loss, the mesenteric fat pad that normally separates the SMA from the duodenum can diminish. This can lead to compression of the duodenum between the SMA and the aorta, causing a mechanical obstruction. This obstruction results in postprandial abdominal pain and vomiting, which can be relieved by positions (such as the fetal or prone position) that reduce the compression.
clinicalPearls: SMA Syndrome is often associated with significant weight loss and decreased mesenteric fat.
A classic sign is relief of pain when lying prone or in the left lateral decubitus position.
Treatment includes small, frequent meals, high-calorie nutrition (often via nasojejunal tube to bypass the obstruction), and potentially surgical intervention to release the compression.

questionTrap.trap: Assuming the vomiting is solely due to psychological purging behavior (a2).
questionTrap.howToOvercome: While psychological factors can contribute to vomiting in anorexia nervosa, the imaging findings (Aorta-SMA angle < 25 degrees) and positional relief of pain strongly suggest a mechanical obstruction. Consider structural causes when physical findings support them.

mnemonic.title: SMA Syndrome: The Nutcracker Effect
mnemonic.expansion: Loss of fat pad leads to compression of the duodenum between the Superior Mesenteric Artery and the Aorta, causing obstruction and pain.

exhibits.title: SBAR Summary
exhibits.content:
Situation: Client reports postprandial nausea and sharp epigastric pain.
Background: Client has lost 40 lbs in 3 months due to anorexia nervosa.
Assessment: Pain is partially relieved when the client lies in the fetal or prone position.

exhibits.title: Abdominal CT with Oral Contrast
exhibits.content: Compression of the third portion of the duodenum between the aorta and the superior mesenteric artery (SMA). Aortomesenteric angle measures 8 degrees (normal range: 25-60 degrees).

exhibits.title: Physical Examination Findings
exhibits.content: Visible peristalsis in the upper abdomen. Succussion splash auscultated over the stomach 3 hours after eating.
